Then those people are idiots.  They should probably suck it up and play better.

Some people are more sensitive by nature than others. You can't just tell someone with a missing leg to "suck it up and run faster." Similarly, we need to respect one another and have some respect for their feelings.

There are some people that are denying that harassment is a bad thing. 
There are people who actually think that the _small_ chance their abuse will cause their teammate to perform better is worth the overwhelmingly large probability that their abuse will, in fact, cause their teammate to perform worse and feel like absolute shit.
**If you think verbal abuse is okay, it's probably because you've been verbally and emotionally abused into thinking it's okay.**
**Just because harassment and abuse 'empowers you', doesn't mean that it won't cause other people to give up. **
Your harassment isn't constructive. Your harassment isn't 'the cold hard truth'. It isn't helpful. It's harassment. 
You aren't in the right. You're a jerk.

That's just some PC bullshit. It totally depends on the person.

In most sports coaches will demoilazie their teammates to ensure they do better. Even in Personal Coaches do this. Calling you out to do better.

I consider myself a jack of all trades but when I start lacking at something the thought of me under preforming makes me do better. Back when I played Football, my teammates pulled a Kurt Angle on me telling mw how bad I was to get me mad and to overshoot my boundaries and do better.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DhPFQzxhWeY

How I played in HS Football gave me the name Knalxz the Destroyer, hence, why I'm Knalxz here.

 I was inspired to not only be a better gamer, son, boy friend and nerd. Hate can lead to many things, just ask the Sith. XD

Except that coaches (generally) aren't random people picked off the streets, they're (usually) professionals who have been trained and taught exactly HOW and HOW MUCH to taunt, ridicule, and berate players to improve their performance. Even your fellow teammates (probably) genuinely wanted you to do better and said what they knew (from however much time spent getting to know you) would push you to do better.

This is why I hate sports metaphors for this behavior. These aren't fellow teammates that you've played alongside all season, and they aren't trained professionals. They're just random people who know nothing about you venting their emotional and possibly daddy/mommy issues by belittling you because it makes them feel better about themselves. Nothing more. Don't give any kind of credence to their ranting. Because sure as hell they don't have your personal and professional development at heart, just a lot of anger and - quite frankly - stupidity.

Teammates in sports are in it for themselves. If they see you performing terribly they aren't yelling at you because they have your interests at heart, they do it because they hate you for bringing them down with you and want you to stop sucking so they don't have to do more push-ups and burpies. Coaches taunt and yell for the same reasons, because you're weak and you're bringing down the team. It doesn't matter if they know you or not.

The difference is you can channel anger into a physical sport way easier than something like Chess or League.

Anger can actually makes you perform far far worse.

Anger triggers the body’s ‘fight or flight’ response. Other emotions that trigger this response include fear, excitement and anxiety. The adrenal glands flood the body with stress hormones, such as adrenaline and cortisol.

The brain shunts blood away from the gut and towards the muscles, in preparation for physical exertion. Heart rate, blood pressure and respiration increase, the body temperature rises and the skin perspires. The mind is sharpened and focused.
(FIGHT OR AFK FOR A FREE LEAVER BUSTER)
Many people express their anger in inappropriate and harmful ways, including:
Anger explosions – some people have very little control over their anger and tend to explode in rages. Raging anger may lead to physical abuse or violence. A person who doesn’t control their temper can isolate themselves from family and friends. Some people who fly into rages have low self-esteem, and use their anger as a way to manipulate others and feel powerful.
Anger repression – some people consider that anger is an inappropriate or ‘bad’ emotion, and choose to suppress it. However, bottled anger often turns into depression and anxiety. Some people vent their bottled anger at innocent parties, such as children or pets.
(STARTING TO SEE SOMETHING ABOUT MANY OR EVERYONE)

Suggestions on how to express your anger in healthy ways include:
If you feel out of control, walk away from the situation temporarily, until you cool down.
Recognise and accept the emotion as normal and part of life.
Try to pinpoint the exact reasons why you feel angry.
Once you have identified the problem, consider coming up with different strategies on how to remedy the situation.
Do something physical, such as going for a run or playing sport.
(DO SOMETHING PHYSICAL SUCH AS GOING FOR A RUN OR PLAYING A SPORT AND GET A LEAVER BUSTER FOR GOING AFK IN YOUR RANKED GAME BECAUSE YOUR TEAM IS A BUNCH OF ASSHOLES)

The way you typically express anger may take some time to modify. Suggestions include:
Keep a diary of your anger outbursts, to try and understand how and why you get mad.
Consider assertiveness training, or learning about techniques of conflict resolution.
Learn relaxation techniques, such as meditation or yoga.
See a counsellor or psychologist if you still feel angry about events that occurred in your past.
Exercise regularly.
(LEARN RELAXATION TECHNIQUES DID ANYONE FORGET THIS IS A VIDEO GAME?)

People who are stressed are more likely to experience anger. Numerous worldwide studies have documented that regular exercise can improve mood and reduce stress levels. This may be because physical exertion burns up stress chemicals, and it also boosts production of mood-regulating neurotransmitters in the brain, including endorphins and catecholamines.
(YOU DON'T KNOW THE PERSON BEHIND THE KEYBOARD, DON'T SAY YOU FUCKED THEIR MOM)

Expressing anger appropriately is a learned behaviour. Suggestions on helping your child to deal with strong feelings include:
Lead by example.
Let them know that anger is natural and should be expressed appropriately.
Treat your child’s feelings with respect.
Teach practical problem-solving skills.
Encourage open and honest communication in the home.
Allow them to express their anger in appropriate ways.
Explain the difference between aggression and anger.
Punish aggression or violence, but not appropriately expressed anger.
Teach your child different ways of calming and soothing themselves.
(BY CHILDREN THIS MEANS LEAGUE PLAYERS)

Where to get help
Your doctor
Counsellor

The long-term physical effects of uncontrolled anger include increased anxiety, high blood pressure and headache.
Anger is a positive and useful emotion, if it is expressed appropriately.
Long-term strategies for anger management include regular exercise, learning relaxation techniques and counselling.

I mean I don't think you can expect everybody to not get mad when their teammate is feeding in a competitive game in ranked. You can mute your teammates to stop them from talking shit, but there's no magical button to make your teammates suck less. Kappa

If they are feeding, well then it is what it is. Unfortunately matchmaking isn't perfect, but you might as well make the best of the situation at hand, you gain nothing from berating someone who is doing poorly in your ranked game. You can either insult them and lose LP on top of a chat restriction, or you can give them advice and try to pull out a win.

EDIT: Or you could remain silent and do your personal best. I completely understand that some games are unwinnable, but you flaming someone isn't going to do anything to change the outcome of the game, all it does is make you a target of the Tribunal. Sometimes you just have to eat an undeserved loss, take a 5min break, get some water, and resolve to make the most of next game.
